title: 103_hr3823
content: The "Welfare Fairness Act" may be cited as the short title of this Act. The findings section follows. The Congress finds that the current variation in benefit levels for Aid to Families with Dependent Children (AFDC) from State to State discourages families from remaining in their home communities, which complicates decisions on where to live. This disparity in benefits also results in taxpayers in some States paying more while others pay well below the poverty level. Uniform AFDC benefits should be determined federally to address disparities in the system for both taxpayers and AFDC recipients, as poverty does not recognize State boundaries. Establishment of the "Commission on Welfare Fairness" to address disparities in the AFDC system and ensure uniform benefits nationally. The Commission on Welfare Fairness, within 1 year of formation, must establish a uniform standard of need for recipients of aid to families with dependent children, adjust it annually for cost of living differences among states, and offset incentives for interstate migration. The Commission on Welfare Fairness, established within a year, must set a standard of need for aid recipients, adjust it annually for cost of living variations, and prevent incentives for interstate migration. The Commission consists of 15 members appointed by the President, with experience in social services or representing lower-income advocacy groups, and representing various regions of the United States. Each member serves staggered terms of office. The Commission on Welfare Fairness consists of 15 members appointed by the President with staggered 6-year terms, except for initial appointees who serve 2 or 4 years. Vacancies are filled for the remainder of the predecessor's term. Members do not receive compensation except for travel expenses. The Commission on Welfare Fairness consists of 15 members appointed by the President with staggered 6-year terms. Vacancies are filled for the remainder of the predecessor's term. 8 members constitute a quorum for meetings, with the Chairperson and Vice Chairperson elected by the members. Meetings are held at the call of the Chairperson or a majority of the members. SEC. 6. DIRECTOR AND STAFF OF COMMISSION; EXPERTS AND CONSULTANTS. The Chairperson of the Commission may appoint a director and additional personnel without regard to certain regulations, with pay limitations. The Chairperson can also appoint experts and consultants as needed. The Chairperson of the Commission can appoint personnel and experts without regard to regulations, and federal agencies can detail personnel to assist the Commission as needed. The Commission has powers to appoint personnel and experts without regulations. The Commission has the authority to hold hearings, gather information from various areas in the US, and allow public participation. Members and agents can take actions authorized by the Commission, and the Commission can obtain official data directly. The Commission has the authority to obtain official data directly from any US department or agency as necessary for this Act. The head of the department or agency must provide the information upon request of the Chairperson, unless prohibited by law. The Commission is also permitted to use the United States mails like other government departments and agencies. The Commission is authorized to obtain official data from US departments or agencies as needed. The head of the department must provide information upon request, and the Commission can use the United States mails like other government entities. The Commission is required to submit reports on the uniform standard of need and its adjustments to the President, Secretary of Health and Human Services, and relevant congressional committees. Subsequent reports must review the success of the standard in reducing interstate migration for increased aid payments. The Commission must submit reports on the standard of need and its impact on reducing interstate migration for increased aid payments under State plans approved under the Social Security Act. The Commission will terminate 6 years after reaching 8 members, and the termination provision of the Federal Advisory Committee Act does not apply. Conforming amendments will be made. The Social Security Act is amended to include a new provision regarding the State's standard of need for a family, which will be determined by the Commission on Welfare Fairness during its existence and adjusted accordingly. After the Commission's termination, the standard of need will be determined differently. The Social Security Act is amended to establish a uniform standard of need for families by the Commission on Welfare Fairness. After the Commission's termination, the standard of need will be adjusted according to a formula and method set by the Secretary. The amendments apply to payments under part A of the Act for calendar quarters after the Commission establishes the standard of need.
